WeeklyEducationalTopic.title: WeeklyEducationalTopic
WeeklyEducationalTopic.description: Represents a weekly educational topic with associated content for the interactive story player.

id.description: Unique identifier for the weekly educational topic.

title.description: The title of the weekly educational topic.

date.description: The date the topic was created.

guidelineCategory.description: The guideline category for the topic (e.g., Nigerian Solutions, Critical Thinking, Historical Context, Unity & Identity).

StoryPage.title: StoryPage
StoryPage.description: Represents a single page within a WeeklyEducationalTopic's story.

id.description: Unique identifier for the story page.

text.description: The text content for the story page.

imageUrl.description: URL of the image associated with the story page.

audioUrl.description: URL of the audio associated with the story page.

definition.description: Stores weekly educational topics. Includes denormalized array of story pages (text, imageUrl, audioUrl).

params.name: weeklyEducationalTopicId
params.description: Unique identifier for the weekly educational topic.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to support the 'Our mumu don do' application, focusing on weekly educational topics and interactive stories. It follows the principles of Authorization Independence, Structural Segregation, and Access Modeling to ensure security and scalability. We store the stories as an array of objects inside the `weeklyEducationalTopics` collection.

*   **/weeklyEducationalTopics/{weeklyEducationalTopicId}**: This collection stores the core educational topics.  Each document contains metadata about the topic (title, date, guidelineCategory) and denormalized story pages as an array of objects (text, imageUrl, audioUrl).

This structure achieves **Authorization Independence** because there are no subcollections and thus no need for hierarchical authorization. All data required to display the content is self-contained within the `weeklyEducationalTopics` documents.  Since authorization is managed via an ADMIN_PASSWORD environment variable instead of user-based security rules, all data is treated as public. No user-specific `get()` calls are necessary in security rules (if we had any). This ensures atomic operations and simplifies debugging.

This structure provides for the required **QAPs** (rules are not filters).  Since all data within the `weeklyEducationalTopics` collection is treated as publicly accessible, listing operations are straightforward and efficient, without requiring complex filtering logic in security rules (again, assuming we have any security rules).

Denormalization is employed by embedding the story pages within the `weeklyEducationalTopics` document. This reduces the number of reads required to display a story, improving performance and simplifying data retrieval. While this might lead to larger document sizes, it's acceptable given the expected size of the story pages and the read-heavy nature of the application.
